title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: vignette, explore High-Fat High-Sugar (HFHS) case study using LUPINE R package. aim demonstrate LUPINE can used analyse visualise microbiome data mice normal diet HFHS diet. focus Day 7 diets. conduct network analyses, visualise networks, compare using IVI values, network distance, Mantel test. Additionally, examine top 15 associations diets using bootstrap-based p-values.

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: First, load necessary libraries:
code: library(LUPINE) library(ggplot2) # ggplot library(RColorBrewer) # brewer.pal library(circlize) # colorRamp2 library(igraph) # graph.adjacency library(dplyr) # mutate library(tidygraph) # activate library(ggraph) # ggraph library(mixOmics) # pca library(ComplexHeatmap) # Heatmap library(patchwork) # plotting library(cowplot) # plotting library(qs) # qread set.seed(1234)

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: assess effect diet gut microbiome, 47 C57/B6 female black mice fed either HFHS normal diet. Faecal samples collected Days 0, 1, 4, 7. raw data included 1,172 taxa across four time points. removed one outlier mouse normal diet group due unusually large library size. filtering, retained 102, 107, 105, 91 taxa normal diet across Days 0, 1, 4, 7, respectively. HFHS diet, numbers 99, 147, 85, 92 taxa, respectively. data saved OTUdata_Normal OTUdata_HFHS within HFHSdata object. load HFHSdata object, contains OTU data, sample information, taxonomy information, library sizes, excluded taxa normal HFHS diets.
code: data("HFHSdata")

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: use LUPINE infer co-occurrence networks normal HFHS diets. inferred networks saved net_Normal net_HFHS.
code: net_Normal <- LUPINE(HFHSdata$OTUdata_Normal,   is.transformed = FALSE,   lib_size = HFHSdata$Lib_Normal, ncomp = 1, single = FALSE,   excluded_taxa = HFHSdata$low_Normal_taxa, cutoff = 0.05 ) qsave(net_Normal, "output/net_Normal.qs")  net_HFHS <- LUPINE(HFHSdata$OTUdata_HFHS,   is.transformed = FALSE,   lib_size = HFHSdata$Lib_HFHS, ncomp = 1, single = FALSE,   excluded_taxa = HFHSdata$low_HFHS_taxa, cutoff = 0.05 ) qsave(net_HFHS, "output/net_HFHS.qs")

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: Day 7, observe fewer connections among nodes belonging Bacteroidales order HFHS diet group compared normal diet group. normal diet group, nodes Erysipelotrichales order connected Bacteroidales order. However, HFHS diet group, nodes Erysipelotrichales show connections Lactobacillales order.
code: net_Normal <- qread("output/net_Normal.qs") net_HFHS <- qread("output/net_HFHS.qs")  Day0 <- HFHSdata$OTUdata_Normal[, , 1] taxa_info <- HFHSdata$filtered_taxonomy[colnames(Day0), ] taxa_info$X5 <- factor(taxa_info$X5) col_vec <- rep(   c(     "green", "gray", "darkgreen", "darkred", "firebrick2", "pink",     "tomato", "orange", "blue", "purple", "hotpink", "lightblue"   ),   summary(taxa_info$X5) )  p1 <- netPlot_HFHS(net_Normal[[3]], col_vec, "Normal Day7") p2 <- netPlot_HFHS(net_HFHS[[3]], col_vec, "HFHS Day7") (p1 + p2)

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: apply two approaches compare inferred networks: network distance measure quantitatively evaluate network topology node-wise measure assess influence individual nodes within network. also conduct hypothesis tests examine differences network pairs.

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: use Graph Diffusion Distance (GDD) measure pairwise differences network topologies. GDD evaluates average similarity two networks analysing information flow connectivity heat diffusion process graphs.  pairwise network distance matrix indicates networks inferred normal diet group similar HFHS diet group. number networks increases, pairwise distances compare. Therefore, employ Multidimensional Scaling (MDS) visualise network distances 2D space, allowing global assessment network similarities differences.
code: dst <- distance_matrix(c(net_Normal, net_HFHS)) dst #>           [,1]      [,2]      [,3]      [,4]      [,5]     [,6] #> [1,]  0.000000  5.112057  4.589908 10.300243 11.008551 11.19028 #> [2,]  5.112057  0.000000  4.456630 10.521769 10.938152 11.12112 #> [3,]  4.589908  4.456630  0.000000 10.296871 10.444232 10.62990 #> [4,] 10.300243 10.521769 10.296871  0.000000  9.733988  9.51460 #> [5,] 11.008551 10.938152 10.444232  9.733988  0.000000  4.05905 #> [6,] 11.190284 11.121117 10.629899  9.514600  4.059050  0.00000 image(1:ncol(dst), 1:ncol(dst), dst,   axes = FALSE, xlab = "",   ylab = "", col = hcl.colors(600, "YlOrRd", rev = TRUE)[-c(500:600)] ) text(expand.grid(1:ncol(dst), 1:ncol(dst)), sprintf("%0.2f", dst), cex = 1.2) axis(1, 1:3, c(expression("D"[1]), expression("D"[4]), expression("D"[7])),   cex.axis = 1.2, col.axis = "#388ECC" ) axis(1, 4:6, c(expression("D"[1]), expression("D"[4]), expression("D"[7])),   cex.axis = 1.2, col.axis = "#F68B33" ) axis(2, 1:3, c(expression("D"[1]), expression("D"[4]), expression("D"[7])),   cex.axis = 1.2, col.axis = "#388ECC" ) axis(2, 4:6, c(expression("D"[1]), expression("D"[4]), expression("D"[7])),   cex.axis = 1.2, col.axis = "#F68B33" ) fit <- data.frame(cmdscale(dst, k = 3)) names <- c(paste0("D[", c(1, 4, 7), "]"), paste0("D[", c(1, 4, 7), "]")) fit$name <- c(names) fit$color <- rep(c("#388ECC", "#F68B33"), each = 3) fit$title <- "LUPINE" # Custom data frame for legend legend_data <- data.frame(   label = c("Normal", "HFHS"),   color = c("#388ECC", "#F68B33") ) p2 <- ggplot(fit, aes(x = X1, y = X2)) +   geom_text(aes(label = name),     parse = TRUE, hjust = 0.5, vjust = 1.5,     show.legend = FALSE   ) +   geom_point(size = 3, col = fit$color) +   labs(y = "MDS2", x = "MDS1") +   xlim(c(-5.5, 6.5)) +   ylim(-7, 2.5) +   facet_wrap(~title)  +   # Add legend points   geom_point(data = legend_data, aes(x = 1000, y = -1000, color = label),              size = 3, show.legend = TRUE) +   # Manually set colors for the legend   scale_color_manual(values = c("Normal" = "#388ECC", "HFHS" = "#F68B33"),                      name = "Diet")  p2

what: Testing the network correlations using Mantel test
title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: use Mantel test assess correlation network distance matrix pairwise distance matrix. non-parametric test evaluates whether two distance matrices significantly correlated.

previous_headings: Network comparisons > Testing the network correlations using Mantel test
title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: Mantel test results indicate networks normal diet group significantly correlated HFHS diet networks Day 1. However, normal diet networks significantly correlated HFHS diet networks Days 4 7.
code: rownames(mantel_res) <- rep(paste0("D", c(1, 4, 7)), 2)  combined_breaks <- c(seq(0, 0.05, 0.001), seq(0.0501, 1, 0.001)) combined_colors <- c(   rev(colorRampPalette(brewer.pal(9, "RdPu")[1:5])(51)),   colorRampPalette(brewer.pal(9, "Blues"))(950) ) combined_ramp <- colorRamp2(combined_breaks, combined_colors)  col_ha <- HeatmapAnnotation(   col_labels = anno_text(rownames(mantel_res),     rot = 360,     gp = gpar(       col = c(rep("#388ECC", 3), rep("#F68B33", 3)),       fontsize = 14     )   ) )  ComplexHeatmap::Heatmap(mantel_res,   col = combined_ramp,   show_heatmap_legend = F,   border = 0, name = "p-value",   cluster_rows = F, cluster_columns = F,   top_annotation = col_ha,   row_names_gp = gpar(col = c(rep("#388ECC", 3), rep("#F68B33", 3)), cex = 1.2),   cell_fun = function(j, i, x, y, width, height, fill) {     grid.text(sprintf("%.2f", mantel_res[i, j]), x, y, gp = gpar(fontsize = 12))   } )

title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: IVI analysis shows Day 7 network normal diet group higher IVI values Bacteroidales Erysipelotrichales orders compared HFHS diet network. Conversely, HFHS diet network Day 7 exhibits higher IVI values across Lactobacillales nodes. perform Principal Component Analysis (PCA) visualise IVI values 2D space, highlighting strongest patterns capturing variance data.  PCA plot, like MDS plot, reveals networks normal diet group similar HFHS diet group. Additionally, normal diet networks Day 7 similar Day 4 HFHS diet networks Day 7.
code: IVI_Normal <- IVI_values(net_Normal, "Normal", c(2, 4, 7)) IVI_HFHS <- IVI_values(net_HFHS, "HFHS", c(2, 4, 7)) IVI_comb <- rbind(IVI_Normal, IVI_HFHS) qsave(IVI_comb, "output/IVI_comb.qs") IVI_comb <- qread("output/IVI_comb.qs")  op <- par(mar = rep(0, 4)) # matrix with only day 7 normal and HFHS IVI scores m1 <- as.matrix(IVI_comb[c(3, 6), -c(1, 2)]) rownames(m1) <- c("Normal_D7", "HFHS_D7") colnames(m1) <- as.factor(col_vec)  adjacency_df <- data.frame(Taxa = rep(taxa_info$X1, each = 2), as.table(m1)) adjacency_df <- adjacency_df %>% mutate(   adjusted_value =     ifelse(Var1 == "Normal_D7",       Freq, -Freq     ) )  # Ensure the variable column is treated as a factor (retains its original order) adjacency_df$Taxa <- factor(adjacency_df$Taxa,   levels = unique(adjacency_df$Taxa) )  # Calculate y-position for annotations based on data annotation_y <- length(unique(adjacency_df$Taxa)) + 15 # Adjust y position  # Adjust the margins in ggplot2 ggplot(adjacency_df, aes(x = Taxa, y = adjusted_value, fill = Var2)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 1) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(     breaks = seq(-100, 100, 10),     labels = abs(seq(-100, 100, 10))   ) +   scale_x_discrete(limits = c(     rep("", 2), levels(adjacency_df$Taxa),     rep("", 2)   )) +   scale_fill_identity() +   theme_minimal() +   theme(     panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),     panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),     panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),     panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),     axis.text.y = element_blank(),     legend.position = "none",     plot.margin = margin(10, 20, 10, 20) # Adjust margins   ) +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = "white", linewidth = 2) +   labs(x = "", y = "IVI") +   # Add annotations for group labels with adjusted positions   annotate("text",     x = annotation_y, y = 50, label = "Normal_D7",     hjust = 0.5, vjust = 1, fontface = "bold", color = "grey33"   ) +   annotate("text",     x = annotation_y, y = -50, label = "HFHS_D7",     hjust = 0.5, vjust = 1, fontface = "bold", color = "grey33"   ) pca_ivi <- pca(IVI_comb[, -(1:2)]) pca_ivi$names$sample <- rep(c("D[1]", "D[4]", "D[7]"), 2) fit1 <- data.frame(pca_ivi$variates$X) %>% cbind(name = pca_ivi$names$sample) fit1$color <- c(rep("#388ECC", 3), rep("#F68B33", 3)) fit1$title <- "LUPINE" p1 <- ggplot(fit1, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   ylim(-260, 150) +   xlim(-220, 260) +   geom_point(size = 3, col = fit1$color) +   labs(y = "PC1", x = "PC2") +   geom_text(aes(label = name), parse = TRUE, hjust = 0.5, vjust = 1.5) +   facet_wrap(~title) +   # Add legend points   geom_point(data = legend_data, aes(x = 1000, y = -1000, color = label),              size = 3, show.legend = TRUE) +   # Manually set colors for the legend   scale_color_manual(values = c("Normal" = "#388ECC", "HFHS" = "#F68B33"),                      name = "Diet")  p1

what: Bootsrap base top 15 associations for day 7 under normal and HFHS diets
title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
code: netBoot_Normal <- LUPINE_bootsrap(   data = HFHSdata$OTUdata_Normal, day_range = 4, is.transformed = FALSE,   lib_size = HFHSdata$Lib_Normal, ncomp = 1,   single = FALSE, excluded_taxa = HFHSdata$low_Normal_taxa, cutoff = 0.05,   nboot = 1000 ) qsave(netBoot_Normal, "output/netBoot_Normal.qs")  netBoot_HFHS <- LUPINE_bootsrap(HFHSdata$OTUdata_HFHS,   day_range = 4,   is.transformed = FALSE, lib_size = HFHSdata$Lib_HFHS, ncomp = 1,   single = FALSE, excluded_taxa = HFHSdata$low_HFHS_taxa, cutoff = 0.05,   nboot = 1000 )  qsave(netBoot_HFHS, "output/netBoot_HFHS.qs") netBoot_Normal<-qread("output/netBoot_Normal.qs") netBoot_HFHS<-qread("output/netBoot_HFHS.qs")

previous_headings: Network comparisons > Bootsrap base top 15 associations for day 7 under normal and HFHS diets
what: Visualising log pvalues for Normal and HFHS diets
title: High-Fat High-Sugar case study
text: top 15 associations normal diet group primarily involve nodes Bacteroidales order, HFHS diet group mainly involve Lactobacillales nodes. However, diets exhibit similar number associations within Erysipelotrichales nodes.
code: # Normal_d7 op <- par(mar = rep(0, 4)) taxa_o <- gsub("o__", "", taxa_info$X5) bpvalPlot_HFHS(netBoot_Normal$Day_4$median_mt, netBoot_Normal$Day_4$lower_mt, netBoot_Normal$Day_4$upper_mt, col_vec, 15, taxa_o, "Normal Day7") # HFHS_d7 op <- par(mar = rep(0, 4)) taxa_o <- gsub("o__", "", taxa_info$X5) bpvalPlot_HFHS(netBoot_HFHS$Day_4$median_mt, netBoot_HFHS$Day_4$lower_mt, netBoot_HFHS$Day_4$upper_mt, col_vec, 15, taxa_o, "HFHS Day7")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Saritha Kodikara. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kodikara S, Cao KL (2025). “Microbial network inference longitudinal microbiome studies LUPINE.” Microbiome, 13(1), 64. doi:10.1186/s40168-025-02041-w.
code: @Article{,   title = {Microbial network inference for longitudinal microbiome studies with LUPINE},   author = {Saritha Kodikara and Kim-Anh Lê Cao},   journal = {Microbiome},   volume = {13},   number = {1},   pages = {64},   year = {2025},   publisher = {Springer},   doi = {10.1186/s40168-025-02041-w}, }

title: Infer microbial networks for longitudinal microbiome studies
text: Install GitHub version :
code: if(!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("devtools") } devtools::install_github("https://github.com/SarithaKodikara/LUPINE")

title: Infer microbial networks for longitudinal microbiome studies
text: LUPINE R package designed inferring associations two microbial species using partial correlations longitudinal data. particularly useful analysing data longitudinal studies, repeated measurements taken time.

title: Infer microbial networks for longitudinal microbiome studies
text: LUPINE supports two modes: single time point analysis (single = TRUE LUPINE()) longitudinal mode incorporates past data infer associations. longitudinal mode requires matching samples across time points. Therefore, used missing samples unless either impute missing data (see Case Study 3) remove samples incomplete data. LUPINE correlation-based method, sample size critical obtaining reliable results. rule thumb, ensure minimum 5 samples available analysis.

title: Infer microbial networks for longitudinal microbiome studies
text: need load package run LUPINE function data. Make sure read following sections understand arguments function. data LUPINE designed work 3D arrays, first dimension (rows) represents samples, second dimension (columns) represents microbial species, third dimension represents time points. array can contain count data transformed/normalized data (e.g., log-transformed, CLR-transformed, etc.). default, LUPINE assumes count data. data already transformed, set argument .transformed = TRUE. Note  data contain taxa zero variance time point. taxa zero variance, make sure exclude modelling including excluded_taxa argument. day numeric vector indicating time points (e.g., days weeks) corresponding slice along third dimension data array. values must increasing order match order time points array. excluded_taxa (optional) list vectors specifying microbial species exclude time point. vector corresponds time point, taxa names must match column names data array. useful excluding taxa low counts many zeros, may lead unstable biased correlation estimates. lib_size (optional) input data counts access library sizes, can provide via lib_size argument matrix rows represent samples columns represent time points. Ensure matrix contains zero values, zero library sizes valid analysis.

title: Example Dataset: HFHS data — HFHSdata
text: example data list containing 8 elements: OTU data HFHS diet: array dimensions n=23, p=212, t=4. OTU data Normal diet: array dimensions n=23, p=212, t=4. Library size HFHS diet: matrix dimensions n=23, t=4. Library size Normal diet: matrix dimensions n=23, t=4. Filtered sample information: data frame dimensions. Filtered taxonomy data: data frame dimension. Low abundant taxa HFHS diet: list 4 elements. Low abundant taxa Normal diet: list 4 elements.

code: HFHSdata

title: LUPINE function — LUPINE
code: LUPINE(   data,   is.transformed = FALSE,   lib_size = NULL,   ncomp = 1,   single = FALSE,   singleMethod = "pca",   excluded_taxa = NULL,   cutoff = 0.05 )

title: LUPINE function — LUPINE
text: data 3D array counts transformed data (e.g. clr) dimensions samples x taxa x time points .transformed logical indicating whether data transformed lib_size matrix library sizes sample time point ncomp number components use dimensionality reduction single logical indicating whether use LUPINE single time point longitudinal data singleMethod method use dimensionality reduction single time point excluded_taxa list taxa excluded time point cutoff cutoff value p-value determine significance correlation

text: list correlations p-values days

title: LUPINE_bootsrap function — LUPINE_bootsrap
text: data data matrix (rows samples, columns features/variables, slices time points) day_range day_range range days perform LUPINE bootstrap .transformed logical indicating whether data transformed lib_size matrix library sizes sample time point ncomp number components use dimensionality reduction single logical indicating whether use LUPINE single time point longitudinal data singleMethod method use dimensionality reduction single time point excluded_taxa list taxa excluded time point cutoff cutoff cutoff value p-value determine significance correlation nboot number bootstrap iterations perform
